posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hello Jordus, and welcome!

I'm afraid there's no simple answer to this one - so much of it depends on how you like to play. The two basic types of defensive build focus very differently. The first is to not get hit. Sounds obvious, but there are many ways of doing this, through agility (high DEX, speed, evasion and dodging), not being seen (stealth, invisibility), and not being there (trapping, ranged attacks, using a tank to keep you from harm). They're the three that come immediately to mind, and all can be enhanced by buffs and magic, and, indeed, all work well together, but I'm sure there are others.

The second way is to recognise that you will get hit and compensate for it, through high CON, immunity to being flanked (rendering sneak attacks useless), resistances and reducing any damage that you take. Again, there are many ways of achieving this: innate abilities, mundane means and magical augmentation.

Saving throws should also not be neglected. You can be strong as an ox and be wearing all the plate metal of a battle cruiser, but if you get confused, afraid, stunned, or just knocked on your backside, it's game over.

Of course, there is another school of thought that says the quicker you kill the baddies the less chance you've got of being killed yourself.

It would be lovely to have all of this rolled into one, but alas, it's impossible. Thus, returning to my first point, it all hangs on how you want to play. There would be no point recommending a sneaky, back-stabbing, trapper, when what you want is to stand on the bridge hollering "You shall not pass!". So I'm afraid I'm batting it back to you, sorry!

posts.author: Jordus
posts.content: 1 last question Empyre65. Under the skills It lists the skill then the number of points invested then a number in brackets. For example Discipline 33(44). I am trying to figure out what gives the bonus to each skill picked. Thanks.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Each of the skills gets a modifier from one of your stats. A few examples: Discipline is modified by Strength; Tumble by Dexterity; Listen and Spot by Wisdom; Spellcraft by Intelligence. So the Discipline 33 (44) means that the +11 Strength stat gets added to the 33 inputted points in the skill.

Of course, some skills are restricted by class, and you might not be able to take them at all, or, you might but they will "cost" you twice as much. For example a pure Fighter will not be able to acquire more than 20 points in Tumble, though it will still cost them 40 points (technically, they could get 21, but there would be no real point to that, but we can cover that another time); and they wouldn't be able to take Use Magic Device at all.

In the same way, saves get modifiers: Fortitude is modified by Constitution, Will by Wisdom, and Reflex by Dexterity.

Hope this helps and doesn't simply muddy the waters further

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: My pleasure - just a quick addendum. I hadn't examined Empyre's build before, but the Lore skill might give you pause for thought: it's modified by Intelligence, so you might expect 26 invested ranks to yield a modified 29 with 16 INT, but the Bard class gets a bonus to Lore for each level taken - 'cause it's a Bard - so the six levels of Bard give the extra 6 points in the skill.

posts.author: Stagmeister

Valerfor wrote: Well, the most important part is to actually start playing - and enjoying the game regardless of the build ;)
You're absolutely right, Valerfor - but it's weird, NwN is the only game I play (admittedly from a very small repertoire) where I feel the need to map out a build to its conclusion before launching myself into it. Maybe it's a control thing.

Nonetheless, Jordus, go on, pick one and jump! If you're like me, you'll know by the time you hit about level 8 or 9 if a build feels right for you. If you're one of these determined "I shall overcome," types, fine - me, I just want to enjoy myself, so I'll bin it if it ain't for me. Nothing wrong with a challenge or two, it helps you become a better player, and thus enjoy it more, but a grim slog through a campaign isn't exactly going to inspire you to go deeper, is it?
